intro.para: A particle moves linearly If it moves straight and with constant speed, and so we call its motion a linear motion. Vectors are ideally suited to describe such motions. We just need to learn how to interpret the following definition:

def.caption: Linear Motion
def.para: The linear motion through \mathbf{a} with velocity vector \mathbf{v} is given by

\mathbf{l}(t)\ =\ \mathbf{a} + t\cdot \mathbf{v}
Read this as: ‘ell of t equals a plus t times v’
, with
t\in \RNr
Read this as: ‘t in R’, which means: t is a number in \RNr.
linear motion
A motion of a particle whose location at time t has position vector \mathbf{l}(t)\ =\ \mathbf{a} + t\cdot \mathbf{v}. – Click to see to the definition.
velocity vector
Click to see the definition of the velocity vector of a linear motion.
The variable t is called the time parameter for the motion, and the above equation is the parametric equation for the given linear motion.

section.body.para:
How does vector expression in the above definition describe a motion? We interpret the variable t as time and the vector \mathbf{l}(t) as the position vector
An explanation of the concept of a linear motion
of a moving particle at time t. So, at time t=0, the particle is at \mathbf{a}; at time t=1, the particle is at \mathbf{a} + \mathbf{v}; at time t=2, the particle is at \mathbf{a} + 2\cdot \mathbf{v}, etc. In particular, during the time interval [0,1], the particle has been displaced by the vector \Vect{v}. This is why we call \mathbf{v} the velocity vector of the motion.
